section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: Row, Row, Row Your Boat

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Jane Cabrera
section-block.rac_book_summary: Sing along with two animal friends as they row their boat down a stream. They meet and greet new animal friends along the way!

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65104-1. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera. Copyright © 2014 by Jane Cabrera. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Holiday House Publishing, Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Sing “Row, Row, Row Your Boat.” Then suggest singing, “swim, swim, swim along. . .” Point out that new songs can have familiar tunes.
Invite each child to choose different ways they would travel. One child could act like a bus driver, another a pilot, one could row a boat, and another could drive a train.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera.
Scout the Squirrel really loves it when he learns a new song.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do you say when you see someone you know?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts. Suggest that you might sing certain pages and make animal sounds.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The cat and the dog have started their trip down the stream.
section.rac_body-text: Introduce children to rhyme. Reread the text on page 2. Stress the words stream and dream. and ask children what they notice about the two words. Let’s think of other words that sound the same.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The dog and the cat meet a monkey. What is the monkey doing? What do you have to remember to do if you see the monkeys swing?
Look! It’s a crocodile! To see her the dog and the cat have to row the boat through a narrow gap.
What do you have to remember if you see a crocodile snap?
The cat and the dog see doves. What do you do if you see singing doves?
It looks like they are at the end of their trip. Who is waving hello now?
The dog and the cat are tired from their long trip down the stream. It’s time to sleep. Let’s say good night. “Good night, dog and cat!”
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do you say when you see someone you know?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then use Equity Sticks to call on individual children who want to respond.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about moving to music as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you say when you see someone you know?
When you see someone you know, you say, “h______” (hello).
When you see someone you know, you say, “hello.”
What can you say when you meet someone new?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: While research tells us that reading aloud grows vocabulary, it also confirms that reading in an animated way encourages children to interact more with a text. To get children involved, practice before you read, give children a focus, and ask guided, open-ended questions like “Why did we growl loudly as we read along?”

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Show Pride
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about a time when children experienced a success doing something difficult,such as catching a ball or learning a new word. What helped them succeed? Explain that when children try hard they should feel happy and proud of themselves.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the emotional development Mind Builder as we revisit the book, Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera.
This story is about two animals who meet new friends as they row their boat down a stream. Clifford loves to meet new friends!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread a few pages that give us some clues about the show pride Mind Builder.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look closely at the illustration. Who is rowing the boat? Do you see any other animals?
The dog is busy rowing the boat past a tree stump.
section.rac_body-text: Reread the text on page 9. Stress the words stump and trump. Ask children what they notice about the two words.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who is rowing the boat now? They made a transition.
At the beginning of the story the dog was rowing the boat, and now the cat is rowing the boat. Do you think rowing a boat is something you would be proud of? Why?
This is a new activity for the cat. He must be proud that he was able to take them all the way home. Does the cat look happy or sad? (MB)
What do you notice about what the animals are doing? Who is rowing the boat now?

section.rac_body-text: Reinforce the concept of transitions for children by having them transition to a new place, such as to the rug or a group spot. Then have partners move to music and play a few unfamiliar instruments. As children work with the instruments, point out their discoveries as examples for when a person might feel proud of an accomplishment.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about ways they can move to music.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: We develop emotionally as we grow in experiences. Even before children begin walking and talking, they feel a clear sense of pride when they accomplish something new. As you discuss accomplishments, emphasize that it’s more about trying your best than being the best. (Massey, 2018)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about a time they asked questions to learn something.
Invite children to sing “The ABC Song.” You may ask children to stand up and dance while they sing the letters.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera.
Scout is enjoying the story because the words in the book are also a song that he can sing. Scout loves to sing songs!
You can think about this guiding question as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What animals did the dog and cat meet on their trip?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during rereading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does it look like the cat is telling the dog a story? Can you think of what the story might be about?
Who do the animal friends see in the water that says, “squeak?”
section.rac_body-text: Reread the text on page 5. Stress the words creek and squeak, and ask children what they notice about the two words.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The animal friends meet an elephant. What do you have to remember to do if you see the elephant?
What animal is standing on the tree stump?
The animal friends are closer to the shore.
What animals do the dog and the cat see on the shore?
What animal do you see? What do you notice about this animal?
What animals do you see? Do they sing or do they dance?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? Let’s see how much you remember as we turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What animals did the dog and cat meet on their trip?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you work together to write about moving to music. Invite children to suggest different music they would listen to while on a trip.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who do the dog and the cat meet on their trip?
The dog and the cat meet a l____ (lion) on their trip.
The dog and the cat meet a lion on their trip.
What other animals do the cat and the dog meet?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children learn authentically when it comes to conversational language, but you can still explicitly teach it. That’s why it’s so important to set up the classroom for guided-play opportunities. As children focus and create, foster intentional conversational know-how by asking and answering questions.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Compare songs with the same tune but different words, such as “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star,” “Baa-Baa Black Sheep,” and the ABCs.
Invite children to play Simon Says. Say, Simon says, Moo like a cow. Moo! Cluck like a chicken, cluck cluck. Remind children to only make the sound if you say, Simon says.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week, we are going to read Old MacDonald’s Farm. It is a song on a poster. We will learn all about the sounds Old MacDonald’s animals make.
Scout likes to point as he reads labels. The labels go with the illustrations.
Row, Row, Row Your Boat and Old MacDonald’s Farm are two texts with songs to sing. Let’s see if we can find other connections between these two texts.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Row, Row, Row Your Boat cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to the weekly concept and this week’s concept question:
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Singing and Dancing
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Old MacDonald had a lot of animals on his farm. Which animals do you see?
Who can come point to the cow? What sound does the cow make?
What do you notice about Old MacDonald’s goats?
Let’s sing about the ducks together. Do you remember what sound the ducks make?
section.rac_body-text: Take this time to have children join you in singing the song. Say, Let’s sing and dance as we sing the song!
Invite children to play a variation of Duck, Duck, Goose called Horse, Horse, Cow. Review the rules before you begin.
Provide a writing prompt about expressing yourself through music and dance. Give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Singing, Dancing, and Performing
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Guided playtime is a great opportunity to discuss sequencing. After children sing, dance, or perform, have them review the order in which they sang the song or performed the dance. Use open-ended questions to find out why. This strengthens memorization skills and creates “muscle-memory” for sequencing in other areas.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to express themselves through music or dance. Play 30–60 seconds of an upbeat song and remind children that they can dance, sing, stomp, whisper, rap, chant, or even act silly. Stop the song and make the observation that everyone in the room is expressing themselves differently. Then finish the rest of the song, gradually reducing the volume to calm the class down.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to read Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera, but this time will be different. We will perform this book and express ourselves. Think about what you will do!
This book is a narrative. It tells a story. Scout loves to read stories and look at the pictures!

This week we read a book about animal friends who took a trip down a stream. Along the way, they met new animals. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about the guiding question: How does music help us learn?

section.rac_body-text: Retell and reenact the book together, focusing on different ways to express yourself through music. Call on volunteers or use Equity Sticks to pick groups of children to actively participate in the prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I will sing the words and you will sing them after me. Let’s start!
What are the animal friends learning about the monkeys? Can you make that sound?
How does the song help us learn about the crocodile? What does the crocodile say?
What do you notice about the words prowl and growl?
The tiger makes a growl. What does your growl sound like?
Who can make the sound a tiger makes when he makes a mighty pounce?
What do you notice about the cat and the dog on this page? Can you tell me how they might be feeling now? Do they look happy?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to discuss the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does music help us learn?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to pick 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Music helps us remember the story.
Music makes us sing and dance.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about using music or dance as expression. Then invite them to share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does music make learning boring or fun?
How can you use music and dance to teach someone something?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Not only does music entertain and energize, it also builds language skills for children who are learning multiple languages. Through music, children can gain a better grasp of sentence structure and grammar. Try using familiar tunes so that a child can engage his or her first language as a scaffold.
